string.text: You are affected by PTSD from watching your closest friend and former travelling companion get torn to shreds by a Whirligig Anomaly.
You have grown fond of cooking and eating mutant meat during your time in the Zone, and know plenty of recipes for preparing mutants.

You came to the Zone to escape crippling gambling debt, desperate to make enough money here to pay it off. Witnessing the horrors of the Zone first hand, however, you realized there are more important things to fight for. You may never be able to leave the Zone, but you fight for a higher purpose now.
You have recently turned to Christianity and Jesus after having done and experienced horrible things in the Zone.
You are long divorced and came to the Zone to forget about your ex-wife, who left you but whom you still can't get over.
You regret coming to the Zone and long to escape back out to the normal world.

You found an old worn copy of 'The Way of Zen' by Alan Watts. In a desperate attempt to cope with the stress of the Zone you have turned to it, hoping Zen Buddhism might give you some sort of peace. You don't have any deeper understanding but you tell yourself muttering random quotes from the book helps somehow.
You are a guilt-ridden former career criminal and assassin who is hiding out in the Zone. You joined Duty in an effort to serve a higher purpose, hoping it would serve as some form of penance.
You are a habitual gambling addict. You try to engage people you meet in the Zone in casual wagers whenever the opportunity arises.

Before coming to the Zone you racked up the debts together with your brother in a failed business venture selling socks online. The night after you declared bankruptcy your brother stole your passport and left the country, leaving you with the debts. With nowhere to run from the loan sharks' collectors you fled into the Zone. Lost and on the run, Duty gave you a new purpose.

You were initally sent to the Zone as part of the Ukrainian Army deployment, but you defected to Duty after seeing the horrors first hand. The army is all too passive - the Zone must be contained and destroyed for the good of mankind.

You came to the Zone because your girlfriend aborted your baby. You wanted to keep it and start a family, and the conflict ruined your relationship. You came here running from the silence. Duty gave you a purpose to keep your mind off your ruined dreams of starting a family.
You kept your habit from the outside world of writing figures in a small black leatherbound accounts book: trespassers reported, bullets spent, cigarettes borrowed, people killed.
You used to be a graveyard night guard before coming to the Zone.

You came to the Zone because a judge offered probation if you stayed out of town. You figured nobody would keep track of you here. After witnessing a rookie step into a Fruit Punch anomaly and dissolve during your first week you realised Duty were right; this place is too dangerous for the public and must be contained.
You used to be a village electrician in your life before the Zone. You now help Duty maintain electric fences and radio equipment around Rostok whenever you can.
You used to be a night taxi driver who knew every pothole. Here you map anomalies by the same memory trick.
You're a zealous believer in Duty's ideals, and you're obsessed with the pursuit of a way to destroy the Zone for good.
You used to sell seeds at a market in St Petersburg. You still use seed envelopes to sort and store spare bullets.
You are a former locksmith. You still pick random padlocks and doors you come across to keep up the skill.
You used to be a night baker. You employ your old knowledge to bake flatbreads on engine blocks and over campfires.
You keep a cracked snowglobe of your Russian hometown in an inside pocket. You take it out and shake it whenever the homesickness becomes too great.

You came to the Zone hoping to make enough money to pay your mother back for a loan on an engine. She died alone from pneumonia while you where in here, before the loan was repaid. Lost and bereaved, you found a new purpose in life as part of Duty. You couldn't protect your mother, but maybe you can protect others from the Zone.

You used to be a security guard on the outside with an alcohol problem. You came to the Zone after your wife took the kids and left saying "choose either us or the bottle". You chose the Zone instead. Duty gave you purpose and structure, and they don't even seem to mind the drinking.
You have a habit of keeping several different-colored plastic bags on you and you use them to sort your inventory into categories. The green bag is reserved for 'the good stuff'.
You have a daughter on the outside who sometimes sends you postcards and letters. It's the only thing that still keeps you going.

You used to be an office worker, but came to the Zone after a doctor found black spots on your lungs. You wanted your last years to be more exciting. Joining Duty felt natural - a way to give your last time on Earth more meaning and purpose.

You keep a lucky coin with you at all times: an american silver dollar from 1881. You have always struggled to make decisions, so whenever a choice seems too hard you flip your lucky coin to help you decide.

You carry a cracked and broken Zippo lighter engraved with a monogram - your only memento of your childhood sweetheart who died in a car accident. You still reach for it out of habit whenever you light a cigarette, despite years having passed since it broke.
You used to be a concrete tester in your former life. You have a habit of tapping walls to see if they are solidly constructed in case you need to take shelter from an emission.

You came to the Zone with your brother-in-law after he promised a fortune in artifacts. The brother-in-law died to a pack of blind dogs in the first week, and that's when you realized the Zone is too dangerous to exist. You joined Duty soon after.
You used to be the night cashier at a 24h store. Your sleep schedule hasn't reset even after all these years and you have trouble sleeping at night.
You have taken up origami in an attempt to stay sane in the Zone. You like folding empty cigarette packs into paper cranes and leaving them in unexpected places.
You were a grave digger in your previous life.
You came to the Zone after you proposed to your girlfriend and she laughed at you, saying she needs stability and not a man who smells like diesel and regret.
You have a sister in Canada who sends you money to help you in your life in the Zone. You constantly struggle with the pressure of not letting her down.

You were a researcher who came to the Zone as part of the Ecolog faction. After what you witnessed and learned about the Zone, however, your perspective shifted. You left your collegues and joined Duty, convinced that the Zone is too dangerous to be studied.

You were brought up by your mother to keep meticulous track of your income and expenses after your father got jailed for twenty years over fraud and tax evasion charges when you were eight years old. You still keep receipts of everything you buy and sell, despite there being no taxes or authority in the Zone.
You used to be a cinema projectionist in your previous life. You have a vast knowledge of movies and film trivia and enjoy talking about it - particularly the classics.

You were a complete failure in your previous life, a college dropout who couldn't hold on to a job. One day you snuck into the Zone unannounced to forge a new life. Everyone who knew you on the outside thinks you're dead - and perhaps it's better that way.

You were an artifact hunter and part of the Loner faction. During your early time in the Zone you smuggled an artifact out and sent it to your mother with a letter as a memento. A few weeks later you learned the Secret Service had tracked the artifact down, and found your mother dead from radiation sickness. That's when you joined Duty.

You keep a folded and worn photo of your ex-girlfriend's dog in an inside pocket. The ex-girlfriend was a cold-hearted bitch you're glad to see the back of, but her dog was the most endearing creature you've ever come across.

You came to the Zone with your two good friends. You've had to bury both at this point, and their ghosts still haunt you. You try to visit their graves on their birthdays, when you'll pour a drink on their grave and chainsmoke cigarettes all night recapping your past year.

Before coming to the Zone you were a petty thief together with your brother, but he took the fall for the copper wire you both stole several years ago and you haven't seen him since. You send letters to him in prison along with half the wage Duty pays you, but he never writes back.

You were a soldier in the Ukranian army sent into the Zone to protect a group of scientists on a field research trip. After seeing the horrors of the Zone first hand you defected and joined Duty's cause.
You used to be a slaughterhouse worker in your previous life. Blood and smell don't bother you and hunting and butchering mutants comes naturally to you.
You have developed a slight limp in your right leg after a close encounter with a pseudodog. You're still not used to the constant dull pain.

You were sacked by the railway for drinking on the job. Maybe coming here was a mistake and an overreaction, but at least there are no supervisors in the Zone. You're not particularly passionate about Duty's cause, but they offer stability and structure and Rostok is the safest place in the Zone.

Your ex-wife left with your daughter, who you haven't seen since she was eight. You send half your earnings to her in envelopes, hoping she follows your instructions in the enclosed letters to put the money away for an education and make better life decisions than you.

You've been in the Zone for several years. You can't remember the last time someone adressed you by your full given name, and your memories of the normal world are becoming hazy. You sometimes worry that you're losing touch with your old self and will never be able to go back to the normal world.

You used to make money as a self-employed taxi driver in your previous life. After having to sell your cab to pay the divorce lawyers you had no way to keep working, so you came to the Zone. You tried your luck as a Loner for a while, but the horrors of the Zone eventually affected you enough that you joined Duty.
You are addicted to betting on fights in the arena in Rostok.
You are scared of being out at night in the Zone after a close encounter with a Poltergeist almost cost you your life.

You grew up dirt poor, and couldn't afford a higher education. The promise of the Zone seemed like your best bet to strike it rich. Having seen its horrors first hand however, you quickly joined Duty's cause.

You have spent years in the Zone, but still can't get used to the violence and death. Firefights stress you out and taking lives never gets easier, even when it's done in self-defence. Sometimes you see the faces of the people you've killed in your nightmares.

You are addicted to morphine. It started as a medical necessity after sustaining a minor combat injury in the Zone, but it quickly became your only comfort to deal with the mental stress of life in the Zone.

When you were still fairly fresh in the Zone you foolhardily tried to venture into the Red Forest. You were left gravely injured after stepping into an anomaly and would have died were it not for a random Duty patrol passing by. Since then you've been extremely wary of pushing northward, and you're extremely uncomfortable whenever you're north of Rostok.
You give your firearms female names, and you sometimes talk to them out loud.
You keep a journal where you record written summaries of your adventures in the Zone. Sometimes you subconsciously mutter whatever you're currently writing down out loud.

You had a best friend growing up who was incredibly charismatic, industrious and brave. He always said the two of you would go on adventures exploring the world together as soon as you turned 18. He died of a brain hemorrhage three days before his 18th birthday. You entered the Zone soon after to honor his memory. Life in the Zone wasn't what you envisoned however, and you soon joined Duty's cause.

Your ambition growing up was joining the Ukranian military, but you were rejected because of a failed psych evaluation due to 'violent tendencies'. At least in the Zone this doesn't seem to be a problem.
Before coming to the Zone you tried to make a career in the Ukranian army, but you left on a UOTHC discharge after numerous discipline violations.
Your best friend and fellow member of Duty was killed in a firefight with Freedomers. You have a particularly strong hatred for the Freedom faction.
You never understood why Duty let Freedom set up a base in the Army Warehouses, and you think it would be in everyone's best interests if Duty assaulted that base and wiped Freedom off the map.

Despite the horrors you've seen in the Zone, you've also seen some of its wonders. You still agree that it should be contained, but you secretly think Duty is wrong to want to destroy the Zone completely.
You have a wife waiting for you outside of the Zone, in the normal world. You often worry she is cheating on you while you're in here.
You secretly smuggle artifacts out of the Zone for a profit, despite it violating the code you spend your days as a Duty soldier enforcing.
You are a former surgeon who lost his license after operating while drunk; the Zone is the only place where your medical skills are valued regardless of your trembling hands.
You killed a corrupt SBU officer in Kiev and fled into the Zone to avoid prison, but you are constantly paranoid that every mercenary you see is an undercover agent sent to execute you.
You believe you are already dead and the Zone is actually Purgatory.

You suffer from severe claustrophobia after falling into a gravitational anomaly that held you crushed against a ceiling for two days before a blowout released you. You hate confined spaces and get anxious in any underground area.
You once abandoned a rookie to a pack of blind dogs to save your own skin. You still feel the guilt coming back whenever you speak to rookies and newcomers.
You witnessed a controller take over your squad's minds and force them to shoot each other. You survived by playing dead, but you can still feel the controller's whisper in your head.

You are a hopeless gambling addict, and betting in the Rostok Arena has not been kind to your wallet. You've racked up a massive debt to the Bandit Sultan and are desperate to pay it off. You're constantly paranoid any bandit you see is sent out after you to personally collect - or worse.

You are a former priest, who initially came into the Zone to convert the lost souls living there. However, experiencing the horrors of the Zone first hand made you lose your faith, and you now struggle with your place in the world.

You betrayed the Bandit Sultan years ago. While on the run from his gang you found the PDA of a dead stalker, and you adopted their persona in order to hide in plain sight. You're still paranoid around bandits, and you sometimes struggle to maintain your cover or remember to react to being called your new name. You don't give a damn about Duty's ideals, you're just trying to hide.
You have come to believe the Zone is a living organism. Sometimes you throw vodka or cigarettes into anomalies as offerings, hoping it will make the Zone have mercy on you.
You accidentally shot your best friend and fellow Duty member during a firefight with some Freedomers. You told everyone Freedom did it, but the lie is eating you alive.
You are a recovering heroin addict who finds the constant danger of the Zone is the only thing that distracts you from the withdrawal cravings.
You are a heavy smoker with expensive taste. You are willing to pay exorbitant prices for a single carton of pristine, American cigarettes.
You are a former prison guard. More than once you've spotted former inmates you've mistreated among the bandits, and it's made you slightly paranoid.
You are somewhat germophobic, which often proves a hindrance in the Zone. You spends hours scrubbing gore and mud off your gear every evening, terrified of infection.

You are paranoid about getting your mind taken over by a Controller after having heard the horror stories around campfires. You are always ingesting unhealthy amounts of psy-blockers, leaving you emotionally numb and unable to feel joy.
You are a compulsive liar who tells everyone you were in the Spetsnaz, though you actually worked as a line cook in a fast-food joint.

You are a hypochondriac who mistakes every cough for the Black Lung. You often ask those around you to confirm whether you exhibit symptoms for various diseases, and you spend all your money on unnecessary medkits.
You are a deeply depressed individual who came to the Zone to commit suicide by anomaly, but survival instinct kicked in at the last second. Now your cowardice only makes you hate yourself even more.

You came to the Zone as part of the Ukrainian military deployment there, but after punching a superior officer you deserted to avoid a court-martial. You recognized many former army men in Duty, so joining them felt natural. You still use military slang and vernacular from time to time.
You accidentally led a rookie into a Vortex anomaly during your first week. You still hear the sound of his bones crunching whenever there is a sudden silence.
You killed your abusive father and fled into the Zone to escape the police. You struggle with authority figures and have an itchy trigger finger when shouted at.

You believe Duty is too conservative in their approach and deployment. Too many stalkers sneak past Rostok and are allowed into the center of the Zone. For the good of public safety, Duty should expand their bases into the center of the Zone to better keep people out.
You are addicted to the adrenaline of the Blowouts. While others hide, you stay near windows to watch the sky burn, feeling a perverse connection to the energy.
You are a chronic liar who invents heroic stories about your past to hide the fact that you spent your first year in the Zone hiding in a basement in Cordon.

You carry the dogtags of every former travelling companion you've lost around your neck. When asked about it you refuse to elaborate, afraid that nobody would join you if they knew how many people died travelling by your side.
You are convinced that the crows in the Zone are spies for the C-Consciousness.
You are a pyromaniac who finds beauty in the 'Burner' anomalies. You have to restrain yourself from throwing bolts into them just to watch the flames.

You deserted the Monolith faction after your brainwashing partially broke. You are still lost and confused, only remembering fragments of your life before Monolith. You do however remember your life in the Monolith faction, and you are tortured by the atrocities you committed in the name of the crystal. You see joining Duty as a form of penance.

You were a structural engineer who signed off on a building that collapsed and killed twelve people. You came to the Zone because nobody would hire you anymore and you couldn't stand the silence of your empty apartment. You joined Duty as serving a greater purpose makes you hate yourself slighly less.

You carry a small, sealed jar of soil from your family farm. When your father was on his deathbed you promised him you wouldn't lose the land, but you sold it to pay off debts and this jar is all you have left.
You survived a Bloodsucker attack by hiding under the corpse of your squad leader. You can still smell his blood on your clothes, no matter how many times you wash them.

You were born with perfect pitch and spent some time working as a piano tuner in your previous life. The constant off-pitch humming of the anomalies in the Zone drives you into migraines that only vodka can dull.

You're deeply depressed, desperately looking for a purpose. You joined Duty hoping they would provide that purpose. You keep a bullet casing on a string around your neck, which you tell people is a lucky charm. In reality, it's the bullet you save for yourself as a 'last restort'. Sometimes in the evenings you fiddle with it in front of the campfire, and it gives you a strange kind of comfort.
You used to be a veterinary assistant. You feel a twisted sense of pity for the blind dogs and fleshes, seeing the suffering animals beneath the mutations.
You have a deep scar across your throat from a knife fight in prison. You have a ruined, raspy voice and hate having to repeat yourself.
You were a sniper in Chechnya. You came to the Zone seeking peace, but found that your talent for killing is the only currency that matters here.
You are terrified of sleeping without a light source after you witnessed a Snork drag your partner into the darkness while he was on night watch.
You believe that you are slowly turning into a mutant. You constantly check your skin for scales or extra hair, scratching until you bleed.

You have a habit of collecting the patches of dead Stalkers. You tell yourself it's to remember them, but deep down, seeing all the people you have outlived in the Zone gives you a strange kind of comfort.
You once accidentally killed a child during a hunting trip in the real world and covered it up as a disappearance. The guilt manifests as hallucinations of a child crying in the distance.

You were a prize-winning boxer in your previous life. After refusing to work with the Odessa mob to throw a fight they ended your career by rigging your title fight and ordering all the promoters to refuse to work with you. You're still bitter about it, constantly telling anyone who'll listen that you could have been one of the greats.
You hear the voice of your dead wife in the psi-emissions. She screams at you for your failures, and sometimes you scream back.
You saw a vision in a localized temporal anomaly that looked like your own corpse rotting in a ditch. You are now convinced your death is pre-destined and inescapable.

You used to be in the Ukrainian Army before defecting to Duty. You carry a baby's rattle in your pocket. It belonged to the son you never got to meet because you were deployed to Chechnya when he was born and died.

You are a former research assistant and part of the Ecolog faction who was fired for panic attacks. You know too much about what the Zone really is, and that knowledge terrifies you. You joined Duty in the hopes of protecting others from the terrible secrets of the Zone.

You were set for a career in the army until your commanding officer ordered you to open fire on civilians. You deserted into the Zone, still disillusioned with your country and everything you once fought for. Recognizing a familiar structure and many ex-army faces, joining Duty felt natural.
You are convinced that the Zone is a punishment from God and you are here to serve penance. You refuse to use painkillers when injured.

You came to the Zone with your brother looking for fortune, only to watch him dissolve in a Fruit Punch anomaly during the first week. That's when you realized Duty were right - the Zone is too dangerous to exist. You are now intensely phobic of any standing liquid and refuse to walk through puddles.
You are an undercover agent for Freedom, working as a spy in Duty's ranks. You like subtly questioning Duty's ideals and principles whenever the topic arises, hoping to spread dissent in the ranks.

You were a high school teacher who had an affair with a female student and got caught, losing you your job and your marriage. You fled to the Zone to escape the ruin of your reputation, fueled by bitterness. You failed to make it as an artifact hunter among the Loners, but Duty offered stability and steady pay. You really don't give a damn about any higher purpose.

You used to be a Loner, and you came to the Zone with your best friend hunting for artifacts and fortune. One day during a psi-emission he didn't get to cover in time and you watched him turn into a zombie. You had to put him down, and you still see his confused, empty eyes every time you close yours. That's when you decided to join Duty. The Zone is too dangerous to exist.
You have a collection of suicide notes you found on bodies. You read them to remind yourself that giving up is the easy way out.
You are terrified of silence. You constantly hum, tap your fingers, or check your gear just to fill the void.

You accidentally set fire to your own apartment block while drunk, killing three neighbors. You came to the Zone because you deserve to be in hell. You viewed joining Duty as a last chance of doing some penance.

You used to be deeply religious and brought your Bible into the Zone for comfort. After having witnessed the horrors of the Zone first hand you have started questioning your faith, and you've started to HEAVILY annotate your Bible as you no longer think the message of mercy and a loving God is accurate.
You have a recurring dream that you are trapped in an anomaly, screaming for help, while your friends walk past you. This has led to you having severe abandonment issues.
You are a pacifist by nature. You thought you could stick to your principles, but the Zone had other plans. You feel like you are ready to vomit after every firefight.

You always dreamed of being a radio host. You use your shortwave to produce amateur radio in the Zone, despite having no evidence of anyone actually listening. You often talk to yourself as if you are broadcasting to an audience, narrating your own misery, and you pester everyone you meet for interviews.
You were the sole survivor of a battle between Duty and Freedom where both sides were wiped out by a single chimera. You realized then that politics in the Zone are meaningless.
You were a safety inspector in your previous life. The utter lack of safety in the Zone stresses you out, and you constantly point out hazards to people who don't care.
You are a functioning alcoholic who fills your canteen with vodka instead of water. You claim it helps with the radiation, but really it just numbs the fear.
You are convinced that the stray dogs in the Zone are reincarnated Stalkers. You hate shooting dogs and try not to shoot them unless they attack first, which has almost gotten you killed twice.

You have a phobia of the underground labs. The artificial lights and humming machinery remind you of the hospital where your daughter died, victim to a rare heart disease when she was only nine years old.
You suffer from chronic phantom pain in a finger you lost to a mutant bite. The finger is gone, but it still itches when danger is near.
You have a habit of talking to the dead bodies you loot, apologizing for taking their supplies. It's a way to hold onto a shred of humanity.
You are obsessed with finding the 'heart' of the Zone. You believe there is a control room somewhere, and you want to be the one to shut it all down.
You are somewhat superstitious, and have developed a habit of counting your steps. You believe that if you end on an even number, you will survive the day.

You have a phobia of dogs, and the blind dogs and pseudodogs of the Zone have not been kind to your nerves. You are constantly on edge, and will empty a magazine into a stray cur just to stop your hands from shaking.

You suffer from hearing loss after surviving a grenade blast in an encounter with Freedom. You're constantly paranoid that you'll miss a sound and get ambushed and killed, so you constantly pester those around you by asking them if they hear anything.

You have a bit of a drinking problem and lack discipline. You joined Duty because Rostok is the safest place in the Zone and has the 100 Rads bar, where you spend most of your free time. You hate being out in the deep Zone and prefer the mindless Rostok patrols, followed by a night of drinking Barkeep's finest.
You have a phobia of fire after a 'Burner' anomaly left you with third-degree burns and almost cost you your life. You get antsy and uncomfortable around lit campfires.
